item.title: Pegasus: French President Macron identified as spyware target
item.description: The president's phone number was found on a list of numbers that were potential phone hacking targets.

item.title: In pictures: Germany grapples with flood aftermath
item.description: A massive clean-up is under way, but Germany's flood damage won't be fixed for many months.

item.title: EU plans to make Bitcoin transfers more traceable
item.description: Companies handling crypto-assets would have to collect customer details.

item.title: Record 430 migrants cross English Channel in single day
item.description: Some 50 people, including women and young children, were seen landing on a Kent beach in a dinghy.

item.title: UK PM 'resisted lockdown as only over-80s dying'
item.description: Boris Johnson also questioned whether the NHS would be overwhelmed, his former aide tells the BBC.

item.title: European Beach Handball Championships: Norway hit with 1,500 euros bikini fine
item.description: Norway are fined 1,500 euros (Â£1,295) for wearing shorts instead of bikini bottoms at the European Beach Handball Championships.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Poland send six swimmers home after selecting too many by mistake
item.description: Poland send six swimmers home from the Tokyo Olympics after selecting too many by mistake.

item.title: Anthony Joshua v Oleksandr Usyk confirmed for Tottenham on 25 September
item.description: Anthony Joshua will defend his world heavyweight titles against Oleksandr Usyk at Tottenham Hotspur Stadium on 25 September.

item.title: Covid: Asia follows global shares slide amid recovery fears
item.description: Stocks in Asia follow Monday's falls, but shares in Europe make a brighter start on Tuesday.

item.title: Jonathan Taylor: Oil whistleblower arrives home from Croatia
item.description: Jonathan Taylor was stuck in Croatia for almost a year over bribery and corruption allegations.

item.title: Tony Blair's Irish Famine message not signed off by him, archive papers show
item.description: Files show the former PM's private secretary wrote the statement but could not reach him for approval.

item.title: Beta coronavirus variant: What is the risk?
item.description: There are fears that this version of coronavirus, first identified in South Africa, is

item.title: Heatwaves: What do they do to the body and who is at risk?
item.description: What impact do high temperatures have on our bodies?

item.title: Pegasus: Who are the alleged victims of spyware targeting?
item.description: Jamal Khashoggi's wife and the editor of the Financial Times are among those said to be targeted.

item.title: Benjamin Jesty: The unsung hero of vaccination
item.description: Edward Jenner is credited with inventing the vaccine but his method was pioneered by a Dorset farmer.

item.title: What are the travel rules for Spain, Portugal, Malta and other holiday hotspots?
item.description: What you need to know about going to Portugal, Spain, Greece, France, Malta, Italy and Turkey.

item.title: The migrants hunger-striking for legal status in Belgium
item.description: More than 400 go without food demanding a clear path to residency in Belgium.

item.title: Clean-up operations in flood-hit western Europe
item.description: Record rainfall in western Europe has caused rivers to burst their banks, leaving dozens dead.

item.title: Germany floods: 'My city looks like a battlefield'
item.description: Witnesses voice their grief and horror at the deadly floods in western Germany.

item.title: Flood disaster in maps and charts
item.description: Maps, images and graphics showing the heavy rainfall and flooding that has caused widespread damage.

item.title: Europe floods: Neighbourhoods clear up after record rainfall
item.description: BBC Netherlands correspondent Anna Holligan is in Valkenburg, where some residents have been forced to leave their homes.

item.title: In pictures: Floods kill dozens
item.description: Record rainfall caused rivers to burst their banks, leaving at least 122 dead in Germany and Belgium.

item.title: First space tourist Dennis Tito: 'I was euphoric'
item.description: Dennis Tito paid $20 million to travel to the International Space Station in 2001.

item.title: Horse racing: Inside the abattoir slaughtering racehorses
item.description: Campaign group Animal Aid set up covert cameras in one of the few slaughterhouses licensed to kill horses.

item.title: Europe floods: Residents return home to see damage inflicted
item.description: Resident in Kleivelderweg, deep inside the Dutch disaster zone, find homes and businesses destroyed.

item.title: Drone footage shows flood damage in Germany and Belgium
item.description: At least 120 people have died and hundreds more are unaccounted for in western Europe.

item.title: Germany floods: Helicopter rescues residents from rooftops
item.description: Dozens of people have died and many more are missing after severe floods in Germany.
